string.Text: Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

links.slidetitle: How to Register for PD Training
links.displaytext: How to Register for PD Training

slidetranscripts.Text:
Welcome to the New Faculty Orientation.

The sidebar on the right displays the Table of Contents and the Transcript tab.

You can click any of the topics you have already visited to go back and review them.

On the Transcript tab, you can see the written text of the narration.

On the top of the screen, the resources tab contains important information that you can access at any time throughout this presentation.

Click the ‘Next’ button to continue.

K: Hi! I’m Kate.

H: And I’m Howie.

K: We’re going to help you through this orientation. It’s very important that you complete this module because much of the information presented here will not be communicated to you anywhere else, and it is essential to helping you have a smooth transition into your first few weeks of classes.

H: However, if you have any questions or concerns regarding this information, you can always contact your Division Office or the Center for Teaching Excellence for help. At any time throughout this presentation, you can view the contact information of many different offices and resources by clicking on the Resources tab in the top right corner of the screen.

H: During this training, we will cover the following objectives:

• Tasks for you to complete during your first week here at HCC,

• How to access HCC’s online resources,

• Further training and development,

• And your semester obligations.

K: In order to motivate you to complete this training, you’ll earn points each time you complete a slide or activity or answer a question correctly.

H: Your goal is to earn at least 400 points. You can see your current score at the bottom of the screen.

K: Click the next button to earn your first 10 points.

K: Before you can start teaching, you’ll need to do several things in order to ensure a smooth transition into the semester.

Click on each of the items on the checklist to view important information that will help you get started here at HCC.

After you view them all, a button will appear that will allow you to test your knowledge and gain more points by answering a couple of knowledge check questions.
H: Which of the following should you do at the Security Office in the lobby of the RCF building? Select all that apply.

K: You will be paid twice a month. Choose the correct paydays for the month of February by clicking on the calendar days which you would receive payment to your bank account via direct deposit. Then click “Pay Me!”

K: In this section you will learn how to access your email and other useful online resources at HCC.

To do this, you will need to get your HCC username and setup a password.

This will serve as your login information to access HCC computers, your HCC email address and the HCC Portal, an online environment which we will talk about next.

H: Once you have your login credentials, your next step is to visit the MyHCC Portal to access important information related to your employment and courses at HCC.

You can access the Portal by visiting the HCC homepage at howardcc.edu.

Now, I need your help to access the Portal! Click the link to begin the simulation of how to get to the Portal.

First click on the Tools & Resources button to show the Tools & Resources toolbar.

The last icon on the right is the myHCC button. Click on this button to open the Portal.

Now you’ll need to use your login credentials to log on to the Portal.

Click on the username text box to input my username. It’s hmuniz1234. This is the first letter of my first name (Howie) and the first 7 (or five in my case) letters of my last name followed by the last 4 digits of my HCC ID number.

Now what was my password. Hmm, click on the password text box. I’m sure I’ll remember…

Oh yeah, that’s right!

Now click ‘Sign In’ to enter the Portal.

H: You will spend a lot of time using the Portal so it’s important to know what you can do here.

As you can see, there are 6 main buttons on the Portal Home Page.

You can check your HCC Email, access and download Forms, log into Canvas, view student information on Colleague (on campus only), and view Updates from the President of HCC.

Self Service also has a button here but this is a student service so you won’t need to worry about this.

Let’s explore the three items here that you are going to use the most during your time teaching at HCC: Email, Forms, and Canvas.

Click on each of these buttons to view important information about these topics.

After you view them all, another button will appear that will allow you to test your knowledge and gain more points by answering a few knowledge check questions.

K: Email is the most commonly used form of communication at HCC so it’s very important that you check your email at least twice a week.

Only HCC email addresses will be used by Division Office staff so make sure you look out for emails from your Division to stay informed about new rules, policies, events and other important news.

You should NEVER email students via their personal email address!

All communication must be via HCC email.

If you have any difficulty accessing your HCC email, please contact the help desk by calling them at 443-518-4444, or by dialing x4444 on any HCC network phone.

You can also view the Help Desk number at any time by clicking the Resource tab here.

It’s important to note that your HCC email is different from your Canvas inbox. For more information, please see resources related to Canvas.

Click the Back button now to return to the Portal.

There are many important forms available in this section that are used for updating grade information, reserving audio-visual equipment for your classroom, printing instructional materials, arranging for students to take a test outside of class and many more.

Please take some time to review the forms available on the site.

You can visit this page at any time by clicking the Resource tab and selecting Forms.

Click the Back button to return to the Portal.
Canvas Icon
True or False: Your Canvas inbox is different from your myHCC email inbox.
K: Which button should you click to access the myHCC Portal? Click it now.
True or False: Your Canvas inbox is different from your myHCC email inbox.

To navigate to the Faculty Development page on the myHCC portal, click Menu.

Click Faculty Resources.

Then click Teaching and Learning Resources.

Click Faculty Development.

This is the Faculty Development page.

Now let’s go to one of the most popular resources on this page, the View Your Classroom tool.

Click View Your Classroom on the menu on the left.

K: In this simulation, you will see how you can view images of your classroom online.

First you will need to select the building where your classroom is located.

Click the Health Sciences link to select a classroom in the HS Building.

Notice that this list contains all the information about the room including the computer system, control system, video system, document camera and additional equipment. There’s even documents to help you learn how to use each of these items in the room.

Select HS-114 from the list in the Room # category to view the room.

Scroll down to see images of the room.

This process is the same for each classroom, however each classroom is a little different so be sure to view each of your classrooms before you start the semester!

Click the Next button to continue.

H: As a new HCC employee you are required to complete 5 online trainings.

These five trainings must be completed before you will be allowed to use the computer system at HCC and you will not receive your first paycheck until you complete them, so please do this as soon as possible.

These trainings are completely online and require no login so they can be done at your convenience. Click this link to visit the page where you will find the links to the trainings.

You can also come back to this link at any time by referring to the Resources Tab and clicking on ‘Required Online Training’

Click the Next button to continue when you’re ready.

Base Layer

K: Every month at HCC we offer many different forms of Faculty Development to help you grow as an educator.

You can see what workshops and events are coming up by visiting the Faculty Development Calendar on the portal.

Here you will see events listed for each day. To view a description of an event, click on the event in the calendar. Let’s try that now.

Hover over the Classroom Assessment Techniques on April 29 to see a description of the event.

Layer 1

Now click on the “More Info” link on the bottom left of the event to view more information about the workshop.

Layer 2

This will bring you to the event description page. The event description includes the date, time, location, facilitator name and HCC Index number for the event. You will need to use that index number, also known as the synonym, to register for the event. In this example, the Index number is 9550.

Now let’s practice registering for this workshop. Click the “Click here” link above the title of the workshop to register for Professional Development.

Layer 3

This will bring you to the registration page. First add the synonym or index number of the workshop. In this case that’s 9550. Click inside the synonym box and type the index number 9550. Then click continue to continue with the simulation.

Layer 4

For professional development, you don’t need to worry about the Subject, Course Number or Section Number, so ignore these fields and go straight to the “Term”. Click the drop down arrow to select the term.

Layer 5

Select “2018PD ProDev 2018”.

Layer 6
Click “Submit”.

Layer 7

Great! Now you have added the event to your preferred sections, sort of like adding an item to your shopping cart for an online retailer, however you have not yet actually registered for the event. Click the drop down arrow under Action to Register.

Layer 8

Now select Register.

Layer 9

Finally click “Submit”.

Layer 10

That’s It! You are now registered for the workshop Classroom Assessment Techniques. Click OK to end this practice simulation.

K: The Faculty Development Team can help you with any number of things related to the art of teaching including collaborating with you on developing your instructional materials, using technology in your classroom, conducting informal classroom observations, collaboration on teaching improvement projects and more.

Our primary Professional Development periods occur in May, August, and January however, as you have seen on the Faculty Development Calendar, we hold many events and workshops throughout the year to help faculty further develop their skills.

While our workshops and services are available to all faculty, we know that our adjuncts are not on campus on a daily basis and they might also have different questions and interests than our full time faculty. We have created the adjunct institute to offer workshops specifically tailored to our adjuncts and at times that may be easier for them to attend.

To learn more about the institute and our other services, click each picture.

Orientation

H: We hold orientations for new full-time faculty every year in the middle of August, and for new adjunct faculty each semester in January and August.

We invite you to attend these orientation sessions to acclimate you to the HCC environment and to support your teaching at HCC.

In addition you can also request orientation to your classrooms.

Classrooms at HCC differ in their appearance, so you might need a little extra help with the equipment and the space.

Just email IMFacultyLab@howardcc.edu and we’ll arrange for an orientation.

Consultations

K: Faculty members can schedule one-on-one consultations in the Instructional Technology Lab located in CL 232, which can be seen on this map.

Instructional designers can help you redesign a lesson, develop a classroom assessment, or just come and observe your classroom and provide confidential feedback.

Faculty may receive professional development credit for these consultations, and you can schedule them by emailing IMFacultyLab@howardcc.edu.

Workshops

H: Workshops are led by faculty and members of the Center for Teaching Excellence.

Most workshops are open to all faculty but some are noted for specific groups.

Some of the workshops led by the Center for Teaching Excellence have included titles such as: Teaching Students who are Challenging, Motivating Planning and Assessing Group Work, and Classroom Assessment Techniques, just to name a few.

Watch for emails alerting you to upcoming workshops and be sure to check the Faculty Development Calendar to see a complete list.

Make sure to register for Faculty Development Workshops using the myHCC Portal to receive Professional Development credit.

Adjunct Institute

K: We understand our adjuncts are juggling many different responsibilities outside of HCC.

To support them, we have an adjunct institute held one Saturday each month.

The workshops at the institute are very similar to those held during the week, and both full-time and adjunct faculty are encouraged to attend.

Watch for emails alerting you to these upcoming workshops and be sure to check the Faculty Development Calendar to see a complete list.

Look for the ones marked ‘Adjunct Institute’.

H: Here at HCC we provide many services to support you and make your teaching experience smooth and comfortable.

We offer a wide range of services including A/V Support, A Print Shop, A Test Center, Security, A Library, and A Help Desk.

Click on each of the hotspots on this map to see where these services are located and what they do.

A/V Services

A/V Services provides a variety of media resources and support.

A/V support is available for all classrooms and can help with projectors, document cameras, control systems, microphones and VCRs and DVDs.

A/V Services does NOT provide support for computers. If you need help with your computer, you should call the help desk.

A/V Services also provides delivery of A/V equipment to classrooms, equipment checkout to faculty for college-related business, and training and orientation for classroom technology.

You may also reserve A/V equipment such as an iPad cart for the classroom or Student response devices (clickers).

For more information or to reserve equipment, contact Audio-Visual Services at 443-518-4819 or x4819.

Print Shop

Your Division Office copier is only available for small and quick jobs.

However, the HCC Print Shop will assist you with most of your printing needs and classroom materials such as your Syllabi, Tests/Exams, Quizzes, Class Handouts, Folding, 3-Hole Punch Paper, Cutting, Padding, and a Variety of Paper Sizes.

You can upload your document directly to the Print Shop using a link in myHCC called ‘Print Shop’ or you can email your submission of jobs to PrintShop@howardcc.edu.

You will need to know your cost center number to order items so check with your Office manager.

For more information on Print Shop Services, contact PrintShop@howardcc.edu or 443-518-4834 or x4834.

Test Center

HCC’s Test Center provides secure, accessible, and professional testing services.

The Test Center offers academic testing for currently enrolled students to take makeup exams, online course exams and modified testing conditions for students who require them.

You may not use the Test Center for your entire class to take an exam unless you are an online instructor.

For more information about the Test Center send them an email at TestCenter@howardcc.edu or call them at 443-518-1280 or x1280.

Security

Security is provided by the Office of Public Safety.

Their main office is located in the RCF lobby on the first floor, but you will see officers in stations in all the buildings on campus.

Services include employee ID and Key Cards, HCC parking hang-tags, a Public Safety escort to your car after-hours, Lost and Found, and they also administer the HCC Mobile Alert System.

In an emergency you can contact Security by dialing 5555 on any campus phone.

If there’s an emergency that you can’t convey over the phone, mention that you’re paging Dr. Howard and Public Safety officers will respond immediately.

You can also contact Security in non-emergency situations at 443-518-5500 or at securitydl@howardcc.edu.

Help Desk

HCC’s Help Desk is your place for technology help.

The Help Desk is a single point of contact for technology needs in your office or classroom.

The Help Desk will provide support for setting up your login account, accessing and using myHCC, wireless internet access, your HCC email, Canvas, Colleague, classroom and office software.

For other non-computer related technological equipment needs, you should contact A/V Services.

For more information contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@howardcc.edu or 443-518-4444.

Library

HCC’s Clark Library is located on the second floor of the CL Building. The library offers many services including placing e-reserves, access to research databases, printing, making copies or scanning, and checking out books, ebooks, DVDs, video tapes, and CDs. The library also features a section of books on professional development specifically selected for faculty. In addition, you may also ask a librarian to come to your class to talk to students about research and how to use the library’s databases. For more information contact the library at library@howardcc.edu or 443-518-1460.

H: Throughout the semester you’ll have a number of obligations to fulfill as a faculty member here at HCC.

Some of these obligations occur at the beginning of the semester while others occur closer to the end.

Drag the slider on the Obligation Timeline to view the different obligations and when they occur.

Click “Go” on each of the obligations to view more information about each of them.

After you view them all, a next button will appear that will allow you to continue.

K: The syllabus is your course map of objectives, deadlines, and other information.

Check with your division office about pre-semester syllabus submission requirements.

Check with the Office Manager to see if only electronic copies are accepted.

Ask your Course Coordinator or Office Manager about examples of syllabi that you can use as a model.

Remember that your Syllabus is a legal document so it is extremely important to include exactly what you will cover throughout the semester.

Click the ‘Back’ button to return to the Obligation Timeline when you’re ready.

You must take attendance each class.

Due to reporting requirements related to financial aid, if you assign a failing grade to a student you must include the date the student last attended your course.

The preferred method of keeping attendance is by submitting it directly into Canvas each class.

If you do not use Canvas to keep attendance records, you must submit your attendance records to your division office at the end of the semester.

Click the ‘Back’ button to return to the Obligation Timeline when you’re ready.

Howard Community College (HCC) protects the confidentiality of student education records by complying with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) of 1974 and its amendments.

FERPA requires that you protect the confidentiality of information directly relating to a current or formerly enrolled student, including

• biographical information such as the student’s name, student ID number, and contact information,

• course information such as class meeting dates, times and locations, and

• coursework and information about academic progress such as students’ grades and class assignments.

This means you should not share any of this information with colleagues, other students, or friends and family outside of HCC.

This information should only be disclosed under certain circumstances on a strict need-to-know basis.


For more information about FERPA please take the “Are you FERPAred?” online training.

Click the ‘Back’ button to return to the Obligation Timeline when you’re ready.

K: Comprehensive final exams are administered during exam week, which follows the last week of class during the main semesters.

For the Summer and Winter semesters, your final exams will be held on the last day of class.

Your exam time is not necessarily the exact same time as your class, so be sure to discuss this with your students at the beginning of the semester.

You must have a class meeting during your final exam period even if you have a final paper or project instead of a written test. Your final class meeting should be instructional in nature. You can get ideas of what to do for this meeting from your coordinator or from Faculty Development.

To see the current final exam schedule, click the Final Exam schedule link here or refer to it at any time using the Resources Tab located in this tutorial.

Click the ‘Back’ button to return to the Obligation Timeline when you’re ready.

H: Check with your Office Manager on how to submit final grades.

Final grades are recorded in your Canvas site and on myHCC.

Grades are due within 48 hours of your final exam.

HCC does not use plus or minus grades.

Any student that received an ‘F’ or Incomplete grade will require you to enter the last date of attendance.

Incompletes can only be given to students who have completed at least 75% of the coursework.

Check with your Office Manager if you have any questions regarding final grade submissions.

Click the ‘Back’ button to return to the Obligation Timeline when you’re ready.

H: IDEA student evaluations is the assessment tool that HCC uses for student’s ratings of instruction.

This is how your students will evaluate your course.

IDEA is administered between the 11th and the 14th week of the semester.

The IDEA process is completely online for faculty and students.

Students complete the survey online and faculty have access to response rates in real-time.

At the end of the IDEA process faculty can access their course reports online.

All IDEA correspondence will be sent to your HCC issued email.

An IDEA survey announcement will be sent to you in the 10th week of the semester with instructions on how to administer the survey and faculty resources pertaining to IDEA.

Check the faculty development calendar for upcoming workshops on IDEA.

Click the link below to view more information on how IDEA works or…

Click the ‘Back’ button to return to the Obligation Timeline when you’re ready.

K: Click on the What, Why, and How buttons to learn about Overrides. Note that some classes such as labs cannot override a full class. Check with your division office for specific rules for your course.

What

Overrides are forms giving permission for students to join a class that is full or has already met twice. An override may be needed for Over-enrollment, Late enrollment, or Students Dropped for Nonpayment.

Why

Once the Term has begun, registration is only permitted if a class has available seats and has not met for the second time. Please be sure that you have space in your classroom before you give permission for a student to enroll in your class.

How

It is up to the instructor to allow the student to join the class. When an override form is completed, the Division Office may grant permission for late entry. The division office will then issue the student an override form. The student must submit the override form to the Office of Records, Registration, and Veterans Affairs. Note that some classes such as labs cannot override a full class. You also cannot override a class with an exisiting waitlist. Check with your Division Office for specific rules for your course.

Click the ‘Back’ button to return to the Obligation Timeline when you’re ready.

Students may provide you different types of forms during the semester that require you to take different actions.

The most common forms are from Disability Support Services. These forms typically indicate the student’s approval for various accommodations and can vary greatly so it’s important for you to review each on a case by case basis. Examples of an accomodation is for the student to be provided additional time to take an exam or to be able to type all assignments.

You should contact Disability Support Services for information on how to address any questions regarding a student’s accommodations. You may NOT ask the student to reveal why these accommodations are necessary.

Sometimes honors students may give you a form that requires you to take additional actions as well.

In this case you should contact your Division Office Manager for further instruction.

Click the ‘Back’ button to return to the Obligation Timeline when you’re ready.

You will have to enter grades at two points during the semester.

For main semesters, after the second week of class, if a student on your class roster has never attended, you will need to submit an NA grade for them.

For other semesters check the Credit Section Drop, Withdrawal and NA Reporting Dates for your classes to find out about deadlines.

To do this, on the portal, click “Enter NA and Final Grades” under “Tools for Faculty” .

Then select the term by clicking on the drop down arrow next to “Term”.

For this example, select “Spring 2017”.

Then click “Submit”.

Now you must select the class you’d like to enter grades for.

Click the bubble under “Choose One” to select “History 122, Medieval-Early Modern.”

Then click “Submit”.

Now you can enter grades for your students.

John Barnes never attended your class. Click in the text field under Grade for John Barnes, type the letters NA, for Never Attended.

Then click “Submit”.

Note that Web Sessions will timeout after 10 minutes of inactivity so be sure to click submit often in order not to lose your work.

You will repeat this process for all NA grades you have to give.

This process is also the same for submitting your final grades at the end of the semester.

Let’s try that now.

Click in the text field under Grade for Alex David and type A, to assign him an A.

Then click “Submit”.

Note that in order to assign a student an F grade or an I grade, you will need to input their “Last Date of Attendance”.

This is one reason why it is very important that you take attendance every class.

Click in the text field under Grade for Jessica Parker and type the letter F.

Then click and type “03/26/2017” in the text field under Last Date of Attendance for Jessica Parker.

Then click submit.

Students who wish to audit your course must be enrolled and will automatically be assigned a grade of N.

Click the ‘Back’ button to return to the Obligation Timeline when you’re ready.

Your class roster shows the students currently enrolled in your class.

It’s critical that you check this roster frequently during the term to ensure that students who are attending your class are registered.

Students who are not registered, may not sit in on your course.

Even students who wish to audit your course must be enrolled.

Let’s check the class roster now.

From the portal, under “Tools for Faculty”, click “My Class Roster”.

Then select the class.

For this example, click “History 121, Ancient World Prehistory to Middle Ages”

This is your class roster. You can see the students’ names, their ID numbers, contact information and the number of credits they will earn from your class.

If the number of credits is 0 the student is auditing the class.

You may want to contact students before class begins to introduce yourself and ask them to bring specific materials to your first class meeting.

Remember to only use their HCC email address. Do not contact students on their personal email address.

And please do not share your class roster with students.

Click the ‘Back’ button to return to the Obligation Timeline when you’re ready.

H: Congratulations! You’re almost ready to start working at HCC!

K: Before you go, we have a couple more things for you to do.

Click the ‘Next’ button to continue.

H: Thank you for completing the New Faculty Orientation and welcome to HCC, where you can help our students “get there from here”.

You can register to receive professional development credit by using the index number 3786 for the 2018 fiscal year.

For our final activity, we ask that you review the information about these important topics.

This information is also presented in the tabs at the top right of the screen and can be used as a reference at any time so feel free to refer back to it as necessary throughout the semester.

Click on the pictures below to view information about each topic.

Complete the preparedness checklist on what you have already done to prepare yourself for your first day at HCC.

Review the information contained in the Resources tab.

Review the Interactive Campus Map tab to find out where you can park, the location of buildings and college services and the information about each of these locations.

H: One of the first things you should do at HCC is get your Faculty ID card.

This card identifies you as a faculty member and also serves as a key card to open the doors to your classrooms.

You can get this at the Security Office, located in the lobby of the RCF building.

Click on the map tab to see the location of the RCF building.

Click the ‘Back’ button to return to the First Week Tasks.

H: Please be sure to sign and turn in your employment contract to the Division Office as soon as possible.

There are payroll deadlines on the 15th and the last day of each month.

All pay is via direct deposit into your bank account.

If you do not wish to use direct deposit, you will need to sign up with payroll to receive a debit card which will be credited with your pay amount each payday.

Click the ‘Back’ button to return to the First Week Tasks.

K: The HCC Mobile Alert System enables you to receive instant notification of important campus information to your cell phone, email, or desktop.

It will alert you in cases of school closings, delays, emergencies, parking issues, and more.

Let’s take a few minutes and sign up for HCC Mobile Alerts now.

If you do not wish to sign up for mobile alerts at this time, click the ‘Skip’ button.

However, if you do choose to sign up now, you will add 30 points to your score.

Please click on the link below to visit the HCC Mobile Alerts Sign Up page and sign up for the mobile alerts now. When you’re finished, close the mobile alerts tab or window and click back to return to the First Week Tasks in this module.

K: In order to park in Staff parking spots at HCC, you’ll need to get a parking pass.

You can get this from the Security Office, located in the lobby of the RCF building.

Parking is much easier with the addition to the east garage, however it can sometimes be challenging.

In addition to the East Garage, you can also park in the following areas:

• The West Garage

• Lot A

• Lot B

• Lot C

Which are all identified on the map

Click the ‘Back’ button to return to the First Week Tasks.

AV Services provides a variety of media resources and support.

AV support is available for all classrooms, labs, and conference rooms and can help with projectors, document cameras, control systems, microphones and DVDs.

AV Services does NOT provide support for computers. If you need help with your computer, you should call the help desk.

AV Services also provides delivery and pickup of A/V equipment to classrooms, and can help with troubleshooting when equipment isn’t functioning properly.

Click on the link to view a list of AV equipment available for check-out.

For more information or to reserve equipment, contact Audio-Visual Services at 443-518-4819 or x4819.

Your Division Office copier should only be used for small and quick jobs.

However, the HCC Print Shop will assist you with most of your printing needs and classroom materials such as your reproducing your Syllabi, Tests/Exams, Quizzes, and Class Handouts,. They can also help with Paper Folding, 3-Hole Punch Paper, and a variety of paper sizes.

You can upload your document directly to the Print Shop using a link in myHCC called ‘Print Shop’ or you can email your submission of jobs to PrintShop@howardcc.edu.

You will need to know your cost center number to order items so check with your Office manager.

For more information on Print Shop Services, contact PrintShop@howardcc.edu or 443-518-4834 or x4834.

HCC’s Test Center provides secure, accessible, and professional testing services.

The Test Center offers academic testing for currently enrolled students to take makeup exams, online course exams and modified testing conditions for students who require them.

You may not use the Test Center for your entire class to take an exam unless you are an online instructor.

The Test Center requires at least 24-hour’s notice for scheduling a student to take a test.

The Test Center will also only print 1 copy of a test, so if you need more than one, you should print it beforehand at the Print Shop and deliver your copies to the Test Center.

The Test Center also has a Canvas Site where you can find other important information about Test Center policies and news.

For more information about the Test Center send them an email at TestCenter@howardcc.edu or call them at 443-518-1280 or x1280.

Security is provided by the Office of Public Safety.

Their main office is located in the RCF lobby on the first floor, but you will see officers in stations in all the buildings on campus.

Services include employee ID and Key Cards, HCC parking hang-tags, a Public Safety escort to your car after-hours, Lost and Found, and they also administer the HCC Mobile Alert System.

In an emergency you can contact Security by dialing 5555 on any campus phone.

If there’s an emergency that you can’t convey over the phone, mention that you’re paging Dr. Howard and Public Safety officers will respond immediately.

You can also contact Security in non-emergency situations at 443-518-5500 or email them at securitydl@howardcc.edu.

Help Desk

HCC’s Help Desk is your place for technology help.

The Help Desk will provide support for setting up your login account, accessing and using myHCC, wireless internet access, your HCC email, Canvas, Colleague, classroom and office software. They also deliver carted laptop computers for classroom use.

For other non-computer related technological equipment needs, you should contact A/V Services.

For more information contact the Help Desk at helpdesk@howardcc.edu or 443-518-4444.

HCC’s Clark Library is located on the second floor of the CL Building.

The library offers many services for faculty including placing e-reserves for your courses, access to research databases, and access to books, ebooks, and other instructional resources.

In addition, you may also ask a librarian to come to your class to help students conduct research, develop information literacy skills and learn how to use the library’s databases.

The library can also assist faculty on copyright questions and help secure permissions to use various resources in the classroom. For more information contact the library at library@howardcc.edu or 443-518-1460.
